byline.original: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and KIM BARKER

abstract: Housing advocates and some city officials urge city to rethink practice of selling off debt of apartment buildings in severe disrepair as part of program that allows city to recoup at least some of what it is owed; report by city’s public advocate, Letitia James, reveals that many of these properties fall into limbo in which landlord stops taking care of them or tenants inside.

headline.print_headline: City Sells Landlords’ Debts, but Buildings Face Limbo
headline.main: New York City Sells Landlords’ Debts, but Buildings Fall Into Limbo, Critics Say

snippet: A growing number of housing advocates and officials are urging the city to rethink its practice of selling the debt of apartment buildings in severe disrepair....
lead_paragraph: A growing number of housing advocates and officials are urging the city to rethink its practice of selling the debt of apartment buildings in severe disrepair.
